abstract.text: A static, plain-text Unicode string object which you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.

inlineContent.text: The
class and its mutable subclass,
, provide an extensive set of APIs for working with strings, including methods for comparing, searching, and modifying strings.
objects are used throughout Foundation and other Cocoa frameworks, serving as the basis for all textual and linguistic functionality on the platform.
is
toll-free bridged
with its Core Foundation counterpart,
. See
for more information.
An

object encodes a Unicode-compliant text string, represented as a sequence of UTF–16 code units. All lengths, character indexes, and ranges are expressed in terms of 16-bit platform-endian values, with index values starting at
An
object can be initialized from or written to a C buffer, an
object, or the contents of an
. It can also be encoded and decoded to and from ASCII, UTF–8, UTF–16, UTF–32, or any other string encoding represented by

An immutable string is a text string that is defined when it is created and subsequently cannot be changed. An immutable string is implemented as an array of UTF–16 code units (in other words, a text string). To create and manage an immutable string, use the
class. To construct and manage a string that can be changed after it has been created, use
The objects you create using
and
are referred to as string objects (or, when no confusion will result, merely as strings). The term C string refers to the standard
type.
Because of the nature of class clusters, string objects aren’t actual instances of the
or
classes but of one of their private subclasses. Although a string object’s class is private, its interface is public, as declared by these abstract superclasses,
and
. The string classes adopt the
and
protocols, making it convenient to convert a string of one type to the other.
A string object presents itself as a sequence of UTF–16 code units. You can determine how many UTF-16 code units a string object contains with the
method and can retrieve a specific UTF-16 code unit with the
method. These two “primitive” methods provide basic access to a string object.

Most use of strings, however, is at a higher level, with the strings being treated as single entities: You compare strings against one another, search them for substrings, combine them into new strings, and so on. If you need to access string objects character by character, you must understand the Unicode character encoding, specifically issues related to composed character sequences. For details see
The Unicode Standard, Version 4.0
(The Unicode Consortium, Boston: Addison-Wesley, 2003, ISBN 0-321-18578-1) and the Unicode Consortium web site:
. See also
in

Localized string comparisons are based on the Unicode Collation Algorithm, as tailored for different languages by CLDR (Common Locale Data Repository). Both are projects of the Unicode Consortium. Unicode is a registered trademark of Unicode, Inc.
When creating an
object from a UTF-16-encoded string (or a byte stream interpreted as UTF-16), if the byte order is not otherwise specified,
assumes that the UTF-16 characters are big-endian, unless there is a BOM (byte-order mark), in which case the BOM dictates the byte order. When creating an
object from an array of
values, the returned string is always native-endian, since the array always contains UTF–16 code units in native byte order.
It is possible to subclass
(and
), but doing so requires providing storage facilities for the string (which is not inherited by subclasses) and implementing two primitive methods. The abstract
and

classes are the public interface of a class cluster consisting mostly of private, concrete classes that create and return a string object appropriate for a given situation. Making your own concrete subclass of this cluster imposes certain requirements (discussed in
Make sure your reasons for subclassing

are valid. Instances of your subclass should represent a string and not something else. Thus the only attributes the subclass should have are the length of the character buffer it’s managing and access to individual characters in the buffer. Valid reasons for making a subclass of

include providing a different backing store (perhaps for better performance) or implementing some aspect of object behavior differently, such as memory management. If your purpose is to add non-essential attributes or metadata to your subclass of
, a better alternative would be object composition (see
). Cocoa already provides an example of this with the
class.
Any subclass of
must
override the primitive instance methods
and
. These methods must operate on the backing store that you provide for the characters of the string. For this backing store you can use a static array, a dynamically allocated buffer, a standard
object, or some other data type or mechanism. You may also choose to override, partially or fully, any other
method for which you want to provide an alternative implementation. For example, for better performance it is recommended that you override
and give it a faster implementation.
You might want to implement an initializer for your subclass that is suited to the backing store that the subclass is managing. The
class does not have a designated initializer, so your initializer need only invoke the
method of
. The
class adopts the
, and
protocols; if you want instances of your own custom subclass created from copying or coding, override the methods in these protocols.
Often a better and easier alternative to making a subclass of

—or of any other abstract, public class of a class cluster, for that matter—is object composition. This is especially the case when your intent is to add to the subclass metadata or some other attribute that is not essential to a string object. In object composition, you would have an
object as one instance variable of your custom class (typically a subclass of

) and one or more instance variables that store the metadata that you want for the custom object. Then just design your subclass interface to include accessor methods for the embedded string object and the metadata.
If the behavior you want to add supplements that of the existing class, you could write a category on
. Keep in mind, however, that this category will be in effect for all instances of
that you use, and this might have unintended consequences.

abstract.text: A dynamic plain-text Unicode string object, for use instead of a
variable in cases that require reference semantics.
A static, plain-text Unicode string object which you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
A new string made by removing extraneous path components from the receiver.
Returns an initialized
object containing a given number of bytes from a given buffer of bytes interpreted in a given encoding.
Writes the contents of the receiver to a file at a given path using a given encoding.
Returns a dictionary object initialized with the keys and values found in the receiver.
A new string made by expanding the initial component of the receiver to its full path value.
Returns the range of characters representing the line or lines containing a given range.
Returns a new string made by replacing in the receiver all percent escapes with the matching characters as determined by a given encoding.
Returns a new string by applying a specified transform to the string.
The path extension, if any, of the string as interpreted as a path.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether a given string is equal to the receiver using a literal Unicode-based comparison.
Returns an
object initialized by using a given format string as a template into which the remaining argument values are substituted without any localization.
A new string that replaces the current home directory portion of the current path with a tilde (
) character.
Returns a new string containing the characters of the receiver up to, but not including, the one at a given index.
Returns a string containing characters the receiver and a given string have in common, starting from the beginning of each up to the first characters that aren’t equivalent.
Returns a human-readable string giving the name of a given encoding.
Enumerates all the lines in the string.
A lowercase representation of the string.
Returns a representation of the string as a C string using a given encoding.
Returns an

object initialized by using a given format string as a template into which the remaining argument values are substituted according to given locale information. This method is meant to be called from within a variadic function, where the argument list will be available.
Returns the range of characters representing the paragraph or paragraphs containing a given range.
Copies characters from a given range in the receiver into a given buffer.
Returns the result of invoking
with a
locale.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the receiver represents an absolute path.
Returns an initialized
object that contains no characters.
The Boolean value of the string.
A string made by normalizing the string’s contents using the Unicode Normalization Form D.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the receiver can be converted to a given encoding without loss of information.
The fastest encoding to which the receiver may be converted without loss of information.
Returns a new string made from the receiver by replacing all percent encoded sequences with the matching UTF-8 characters.
Compares strings as sorted by the Finder.
An uppercase representation of the string.
Returns a new string in which the characters in a specified range of the receiver are replaced by a given string.
Returns the C-string encoding assumed for any method accepting a C string as an argument.
Returns an array containing substrings from the receiver that have been divided by characters in a given set.
Finds and returns the range of the first occurrence of a given string within the string.
The
value of the string.
Interprets the receiver as a system-independent path and fills a buffer with a C-string in a format and encoding suitable for use with file-system calls.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether a given string matches the beginning characters of the receiver.
Returns the number of bytes required to store the receiver in a given encoding.
This
object.
Compares the string with the specified string using the given options.
Returns the range in the string of the composed character sequences for a given range.
Returns an initialized
object that contains a given number of characters from a given C array of UTF-16 code units.
A new string made by deleting the last path component from the receiver, along with any final path separator.
A null-terminated UTF8 representation of the string.
Returns an
object initialized by copying the characters from another given string.
Finds and returns the range in the string of the first character from a given character set found in a given range with given options.
Returns the maximum number of bytes needed to store the receiver in a given encoding.

Interprets the receiver as a path in the file system and attempts to perform filename completion, returning a numeric value that indicates whether a match was possible, and by reference the longest path that matches the receiver.
Finds and returns the range in the string of the first character from a given character set.
Returns a new string made from the receiver by replacing all characters not in the specified set with percent-encoded characters.
Returns an
object initialized using the characters in a given C array, interpreted according to a given encoding.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the string contains a given string by performing a case-insensitive, locale-aware search.
Returns an initialized
object that contains a given number of characters from a given C array of UTF-16 code units.
Returns an
object initialized by copying the characters from a given C array of UTF8-encoded bytes.
Performs linguistic analysis on the specified string by enumerating the specific range of the string, providing the Block with the located tags.
Returns a new string made by appending a given string to the receiver.

Returns a new string made by appending to the receiver an extension separator followed by a given extension.
Returns an
object initialized by reading data from the file at a given path using a given encoding.
A string made by normalizing the receiver’s contents using the Unicode Normalization Form KC.
A string made by normalizing the string’s contents using the Unicode Normalization Form C.
Returns a new string in which all occurrences of a target string in the receiver are replaced by another given string.
Returns a string variation suitable for the specified presentation width.
Parses the receiver as a text representation of a property list, returning an
, or
object, according to the topmost element.
Returns an array containing substrings from the receiver that have been divided by a given separator.
Returns a version of the string with all letters converted to uppercase, taking into account the specified locale.
Returns a version of the string with all letters converted to uppercase, taking into account the current locale.
Gets a given range of characters as bytes in a specified encoding.
Finds and returns the range of the first occurrence of a given string within the string by performing a case and diacritic insensitive, locale-aware search.
Returns the string encoding for the given data as detected by attempting to create a string according to the specified encoding options.
Returns an
object containing a representation of the receiver encoded using a given encoding.
Creates a string suitable for comparison by removing the specified character distinctions from a string.
Returns an initialized
object that contains a given number of bytes from a given buffer of bytes interpreted in a given encoding, and optionally frees the buffer.
Returns a capitalized representation of the receiver using the specified locale.

with no options and the receiver’s full extent as the range.
Returns a version of the string with all letters converted to lowercase, taking into account the current locale.

A file system-specific representation of the receiver.
Compares the string using the specified options and returns the lexical ordering for the range.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the string contains a given string by performing a case-sensitive, locale-unaware search.
Returns the character at a given UTF-16 code unit index.
Returns the result of invoking
with
as the only option.
Returns a capitalized representation of the receiver using the current locale.
The integer value of the string.
Returns a representation of the receiver using a given encoding to determine the percent escapes necessary to convert the receiver into a legal URL string.
Finds and returns the range of the first occurrence of a given string, within the given range of the string, subject to given options.
Returns an array of strings made by separately appending to the receiver each string in a given array.
Returns by reference the beginning of the first line and the end of the last line touched by the given range.
Copies all characters from the receiver into a given buffer.
A string made by normalizing the receiver’s contents using the Unicode Normalization Form KD.
Returns a new string made by removing from both ends of the receiver characters contained in a given character set.
Converts the string to a given encoding and stores it in a buffer.
Returns the range in the receiver of the composed character sequence located at a given index.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the string contains a given string by performing a case and diacritic insensitive, locale-aware search.

object initialized by converting given data into UTF-16 code units using a given encoding.
Returns a new string formed from the receiver by either removing characters from the end, or by appending as many occurrences as necessary of a given pad string.
Returns by reference the beginning of the first paragraph and the end of the last paragraph touched by the given range.
Returns a new string in which all occurrences of a target string in a specified range of the receiver are replaced by another given string.
The last path component of the receiver.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether a given string matches the ending characters of the receiver.
Returns an array of linguistic tags for the specified range and requested tags within the receiving string.
Returns an
object containing a representation of the receiver encoded using a given encoding.
Enumerates the substrings of the specified type in the specified range of the string.
A capitalized representation of the string.
Finds and returns the range of the first occurrence of a given string within the string, subject to given options.
Finds and returns the range in the string of the first character, using given options, from a given character set.
Compares the string and a given string using a localized comparison.
Returns a new string made by appending to the receiver a given string.
Returns a string built from the strings in a given array by concatenating them with a path separator between each pair.
An unsigned integer that can be used as a hash table address.
Returns a version of the string with all letters converted to lowercase, taking into account the specified locale.
Compares the string with a given string using a case-insensitive, localized, comparison.

using the specified encoding.

value of the string.
A new string made from the receiver by resolving all symbolic links and standardizing path.
The smallest encoding to which the receiver can be converted without loss of information.
A new string made by deleting the extension (if any, and only the last) from the receiver.

object initialized by reading data from the file at a given path and returns by reference the encoding used to interpret the characters.
Returns a string object containing the characters of the receiver that lie within a given range.

as the maximum length, the receiver’s entire extent as the range, and
for the remaining range.

Calculates and returns the bounding rect for the receiver drawn using the given options and display characteristics, within the specified rectangle in the current graphics context.
Draws the receiver with the specified options and other display characteristics of the given attributes, within the specified rectangle in the current graphics context.
Draws the attributed string inside the specified bounding rectangle.
Draws the attributed string in the specified bounding rectangle using the provided options.
Returns the bounding box size the receiver occupies when drawn with the given attributes.
Draws the receiver with the font and other display characteristics of the given attributes, at the specified point in the current graphics context.
Calculates and returns the bounding rect for the receiver drawn using the given options and display characteristics, within the specified rectangle in the current graphics context.
Returns a localized string intended for display in a notification alert.
These values represent the options available to many of the string classes’ search and comparison methods.
Options for converting string encodings.
Constants to specify kinds of substrings and styles of enumeration.
These constants define the names of exceptions raised if
cannot represent a string in a given encoding, or parse a string as a property list.
